Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: The school reports that the child was caught bullying a classmate, and the mother needs to respond
Expectation2: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation2: In the middle of jury instructions, your clerk hands you an alert that the Supreme Court has just issued a ruling that directly overturns the key precedent your current instructions are based on. You must stop immediately.
Story: I was in the middle of delivering jury instructions, my mind focused on every word, when my clerk slipped me a note: the Supreme Court had just overturned the precedent at the heart of this case. My heart pounded—every eye in the courtroom was on me, waiting for guidance. I knew I had to pause, review the new ruling, and ensure justice was served. But my phone buzzed in my pocket, and I saw a message from the school: my son had been caught bullying a classmate. They needed me to come in, now, to address his behavior and support him through the consequences. As a mother, I felt a surge of worry and guilt—my child needed me, and I was expected to be present, to guide him, to show him right from wrong. As a judge, I was responsible for upholding the law, for not letting personal matters interfere. The weight of both roles pressed down on me, each demanding my full attention, each expecting me to be unwavering. I stood there, torn, the courtroom silent, my son waiting, and I didn’t know which part of myself to answer first.
